statement: President Obama called Libya a "Shit Show" and the media ignored the vulgarity.

title: Is Walmart Laying Off 100,000 Employees and Closing 250 Sam's Club Stores?
subtitle: Dozens of Sam's Club stores are closing, but a partisan Facebook page vastly exaggerates the numbers involved.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In January 2018, Walmart announced a plan to close 250 Sam's Club warehouses, leaving 100,000 workers jobless.

title: Is Oral Sex Still Illegal in 18 States?
subtitle: Although some states still have anti-sodomy laws on the books, they are unenforceable because of a 2003 Supreme Court ruling.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Eighteen U.S. states still have laws banning oral sex.

title: Did the NFL Stop Donations to Breast Cancer and Military Charities in Order to Fund Black Lives Matter?
subtitle: Websites misrepresented details of an agreement between the National Football League and protesting players.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In November 2017, the National Football League decided to end its donations to various existing charitable commitments and shifted that funding to the Black Lives Matter movement.

title: Is the Trump Administration Planning to Bring Back Government Use of the Word 'Negro'?
subtitle: Despite misleading claims by a left-wing web site, federal agencies are already allowed to use "negro" as a racial category, though perhaps not for long.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The Trump White House is considering resuming the use of "negro" as a racial category.

title: Are Retailers Using 'Disappearing Ink' on Receipts to Discourage Returns?
subtitle: A long-circulating rumor claims retailers use "disappearing ink" to inhibit the return of merchandise or use of warranties.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Retailers are using "disappearing ink" on receipts to limit or enforce a strict window on returns.

title: Did DNA Testing Companies Admit to Altering Tests to 'Screw with Racists'?
subtitle: A number of hyperpartisan web sites claimed that DNA testing companies deliberately fabricated African ancestry to "screw with" racist customers.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: DNA testing companies admitted to tampering with results in order to agitate racist customers.

title: Do Eddie Bauer Stores Destroy Leftover Clothes Instead of Donating Them?
subtitle: While the company confirmed that photographs taken outside its New York City store are real, there is no indication that cutting up clothes before dumping them is a common practice.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Eddie Bauer clothing stores destroy and discard leftover products rather than giving them intact to charity.

title: Did Germany Release a 'Historic Statement' Denouncing the United States Under Trump?
subtitle: The German foreign minister gave a speech calling on Germany and Europe to more aggressively assert their global roles.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Germany released a "historic statement" denouncing the United States.

title: Is Portugal an Example of What Happens Without Net Neutrality?
subtitle: Proponents of keeping the FCC's net neutrality regulations cited a Portuguese company's mobile data plan as a harbinger of the future.
author: David Emery
statement: Portugal doesn't have net neutrality regulations, and is an example of what happens without such laws; for example, a Portuguese telecommunications company, MEO, is parceling out access to specific broadband apps and content on a fee-for-service basis.

title: Is Taco Bell Roy Moore's Main Financial Backer?
subtitle: A social media rumor calling for a boycott of Taco Bell inaccurately claims that either the chain or its owner is the main financial backer of the embattled politician.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Taco Bell (or its owner) is the main financier of Alabama politician Roy Moore's Senate campaign.

title: Do 'Illegal' Refugees Receive $3,874 Per Month from the Government?
subtitle: "This is what 1 illegal refugee gets with the federal assistance program: $3874 per month."
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Each refugee in Canada receives $3,874 every month from the government under the Resettlement Assistance Program.

title: 'A Little Gun History'
subtitle: An internet post purporting to prove that the worst genocides of the twentieth century were the result of gun control laws includes a good deal of erroneous history.
author: David Emery
statement: Internet list accurately cites historical facts and figures proving that the worst mass exterminations of civilian populations in the twentieth century were the result of gun control laws.

title: Is a Virginia Church Ripping Out an 'Offensive' George Washington Plaque?
subtitle: An Alexandria church's decision to relocate two plaques due to ongoing controversy over memorials to Robert E. Lee was misrepresented as a decision that George Washington might "offend" parishioners.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Christ Church in Alexandria, Virginia, is "ripping out" a plaque dedicated to George Washington because it might offend people.

title: Did the 1938 Radio Broadcast of 'War of the Worlds' Cause a Nationwide Panic?
subtitle: Accounts conflict about how terrified Americans really were by Orson Welles' infamous 1938 "War of the Worlds" Halloween broadcast.
author: David Emery
statement: Orson Welles' 30 October 1938 radio adaptation of "The War of the Worlds" caused mass hysteria, convincing thousands of panicked listeners across North America that Earth was being attacked by Mars.

title: Did the United States Military Ban Green Card Holders From Enlisting?
subtitle: A "hold" on enlistments by U.S. legal permanent residents will only apply to the Army Reserves and the National Guard.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: The United States Army will no longer accept lawful permanent residents, also called "green card" holders, as recruits.

title: Did President Donald Trump Amend an Executive Order to Recall 1,000 Retired Air Force Pilots?
subtitle: Despite rumors, the President did not recall a thousand retired Air Force pilots by amending Executive Order 13223.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: President Trump amended Executive Order 13223, recalling 1,000 retired Air Force pilots in a "mini draft" and in preparation for imminent war.

title: Is an Increase in Recorded Crime in England and Wales Linked to 'Radical Islamic Terror'?
subtitle: An early morning tweet from Donald Trump contains a basic factual error and a grossly misleading summary of official UK statistics.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A 13 percent increase in police-recorded crime in England and Wales is linked to a rise in 'radical Islamic terror.'

title: Is Manuka Honey 'Better Than All Known Antibiotics?'
subtitle: Manuka honey has well-documented antibacterial properties, but the research is too preliminary to declare superiority over all antibiotics.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Manuka honey, as a topical treatment, is better than all known antibiotics.

title: Robbers Throwing Eggs at Car Windshields?
subtitle: Facebook alerts about robbers' flinging eggs at cars to impair drivers' vision and force them to stop are greatly exaggerated.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Robbers are flinging eggs at cars to impair drivers' vision and force them to stop.

title: Does a Coin in a Cup of Ice Accurately Tell You If Your Freezer Lost Power?
subtitle: "I just heard a great tip. It's called the one cup tip."
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Placing a coin on top of a frozen glass of water in your freezer can help you tell if your freezer experienced a significant loss of power in your absence.

title: Did Obama Award Presidential Medal of Freedom to Weinstein, Weiner, Clinton, and Cosby?
subtitle: So many awards, so few genuine recipients.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A meme shows President Obama awarding the Presidential Medal of Freedom to Bill Clinton, Anthony Weiner, Bill Cosby, and Harvey Weinstein.

title: Did Divers Just Uncover the 'Lost City' of Heracleion?
subtitle: Divers did uncover the ruins of Thonis-Heracleion, but the discovery was not new in 2017 - contrary to the claims of clickbait articles.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Divers uncovered the submerged city of Heracleion in October 2017.

title: Did Donald Trump Joke Around, Fail to Salute the Flag During a Military Ceremony?
subtitle: A left-leaning web site correctly points out that the President joked around during the playing of "Retreat," but he did not violate protocol.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: President Trump violated protocol by not standing or saluting during the playing of "Retreat" during an interview with Sean Hannity.

title: Was a Navy Reservist Discharged for Protesting the National Anthem?
subtitle: Renewed interest in protests during the national anthem led to inaccurate and outdated stories about Janaye Ervin's departure from the military.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The Navy discharged a black sailor named Janaye Ervin for refusing to stand for the National Anthem.

title: Is the NFL a Tax-Exempt Non-Profit Organization?
subtitle: Claims that the National Football League pays no taxes on billions of dollars in profits because they are a nonprofit organization are exaggerated and outdated.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The National Football League enjoys tax-exempt status as a nonprofit organization.

title: Did the Red Cross Steal Donations in Texas, Empowered by an Obama-Era Executive Order?
subtitle: A viral Facebook video contains false and unproven claims about the humanitarian organization's actions in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In September 2017, the Red Cross stole donated items from churches in Houston, Texas, and then sold some of the items and burned the others - all under the protection of a 2012 executive order.

title: Were Houston Residents Warned to Use Gas Masks During Mosquito Spraying?
subtitle: A warning video about the use of the insecticide naled in parts of Texas gets some facts wrong and greatly exaggerates the risk to the public.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In September 2017, authorities in Houston, Texas warned residents to use gas masks as they sprayed the area with a neurotoxic insecticide that "causes brain damage".

title: Hillary Clinton Says Women 'Caved' to Men in Voting Against Her?
subtitle: A viral Facebook post misquotes the 2016 Democratic presidential candidate.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Hillary Clinton said women voted for Donald Trump because they "caved" to pressure from the men around them.

title: Floridians Can Obtain Food Stamp Benefits If Their Power Went Out During Hurricane Irma?
subtitle: A series of Facebook rumors about food stamp benefits for post-Irma Florida residents have a grain of truth to them but elide important facts.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Florida residents affected by Hurricane Irma can receive $197 in food stamp benefits, but only if they can show that their homes lost power for more than two hours.

title: Are Police in Sweden No Longer Investigating Rapes Since Migrants Arrived?
subtitle: Former UKIP leader Nigel Farage cited the conspiracy web site InfoWars in a tweet claiming police in Sweden admitted they are "no longer" investigating rape.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Police in Sweden admitted they are "no longer" investigating rape since migrant arrivals.

title: Did Floodwaters in Southeast Texas Test Positive for Several Diseases After Harvey?
subtitle: There is no evidence to support a viral Facebook warning about certain cities, but the public should be very cautious about contact with floodwaters.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Floodwaters in parts of Southeast Texas tested positive for diseases and contaminants including typhoid fever and MRSA in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey.

title: New Research Finally Solves the 'Fibromyalgia Mystery'?
subtitle: The research is real, but it is neither new nor did it substantively affect the debate about the disease's cause.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: New research has uncovered that the true cause of fibromyalgia is an excess number of specific nerves found near a specific kind of blood vessel in the hands and feet, ending the controversy over the disease's cause and mechanism.

title: Are Hotels Required to Accept Pets During Natural Disasters?
subtitle: Neither FEMA nor the 2006 PETS law requires hotels and motels to accommodate pets during emergencies.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The federal government, either through the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) or the 2006 PETS law allows pet owners to bring their pets to any hotel or motel during weather-related evacuations.

title: Is the City of Sacramento Paying Gang Members $1.5 Million Not to Kill?
subtitle: California's capital city has contracted with a nonprofit organization for a pilot program aimed at ending gun violence.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The city of Sacramento is paying gang members $1.5 million to stop killing.

title: Wendell Callahan Pardoned by Obama, Kills Three Victims?
subtitle: President Obama did not pardon a convicted drug dealer named Wendell Callahan, who was later charged with murdering three people after his early release from prison.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: President Obama pardoned a "violent crackhead" named Wendell Callahan, who went on to murder a woman and her two small children.

title: Did Congress Designate Confederate Soldiers as United States Veterans?
subtitle: Debates over monuments led to a rumor that Confederate soldiers are legally considered veterans of the United States military.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Congress passed laws in 1929 and 1958 designating all Confederate soldiers as United States veterans, making it illegal to remove monuments to the Confederacy.

title: Did a Johns Hopkins Scientist Expose Flu Vaccine Dangers?
subtitle: An anthropologist (not a doctor) penned a non-peer reviewed piece arguing that flu vaccination benefits are overestimated and that the risks have not been sufficiently highlighted.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A Johns Hopkins scientist issued a "blistering report" on flu vaccine dangers in the

title: Has the Secret Service Gone 'Broke' Paying Agents to Protect the Trump Family?
subtitle: News reports exaggerate and misrepresent the extent and nature of financial problems at the Secret Service.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: As of August 2017, the Secret Service had run out of money for the year due to the demands of protecting President Trump and his family.

title: Are Vigilante Protesters Digging Up Confederate Graves After Charlottesville Clashes?
subtitle: Despite reports, emboldened protesters in Charlottesville have not started unearthing the bodies of Confederate soldiers.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Vigilante Protesters Digging Up Confederate Graves after Charlottesville Clashes?

title: Did Singer Lana Del Rey Ban American Flags at Her Concerts?
subtitle: In an interview with a music magazine, the singer said she's taken the flag away as a backdrop during the performance of the song "Born to Die".
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Singer Lana Del Rey banned the American flag from her concerts because she can't stand to see it with President Trump in office.

title: Are Memberships No Longer Necessary to Shop at Costco?
subtitle: Clickbait articles on Facebook are misleading users into thinking people no longer need a memberships to shop at the warehouse stores.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: You no longer need to be a Costco member to shop in their stores.

title: Did a New Jersey Town Forbid Residents From Criticizing Islam?
subtitle: As part of a lawsuit settlement, residents are barred from discussing Muslims or Islam at a planning commission meeting.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A town in New Jersey has forbidden residents from criticizing Muslims or Islam in keeping with sharia law.

title: Did Congress Vote to Allow Horses to Be Slaughtered for Food?
subtitle: The House Appropriations Committee ended a USDA ban on funding for inspections of horse slaughterhouses.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: The House voted to allow horses in the U.S. to be slaughtered for food.

title: Did Actor Chris Pratt Say He Likes Hunting Because He Enjoys Killing Animals?
subtitle: A quote attributed to Pratt about the joys of hunting was created from bits and pieces of various unrelated interviews.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Actor Chris Pratt says that he has no problem letting meat go to waste after hunting, because he just likes to kill animals.

title: Did Donald Trump Predict the 'Pizzagate' Conspiracy Theory in a 2011 Interview?
subtitle: Although Trump did mention the word "Pizzagate", he was referring to a non-controversy over a lunch meeting with Sarah Palin, not the pedophile ring conspiracy theory.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Donald Trump referred to the pedophilia conspiracy theory that has come to be known as "Pizzagate" during a 2011 interview.

title: Did Wendy's Replace Workers With Machines?
subtitle: A meme made the demonstrably false claim that Wendy's had replaced workers with machines at thousands of its restaurants, thanks to a minimum wage increase.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Wendy's restaurants replaced workers with machines at thousands of locations because of a hike in the minimum wage.

title: Did the U.S. Food and Drug Administration Announce a Ban on a Colgate Total Toothpaste Ingredient?
subtitle: A widely-shared article gets some crucial facts wrong about a September 2016 FDA ruling on the use of triclosan.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In June 2017, the FDA announced it would be banning the use of triclosan in various products, including Colgate Total.

title: Is This the 1898 Oklahoma Tornado?
subtitle: A centuries-old photograph purportedly showing a tornado in Oklahoma is actually an early example of composite photography.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows two men standing on a road in front of a tornado in Oklahoma in 1898.

title: Is This What Weather Reports in Sweden Look Like?
subtitle: A video comparing weather reports from Sweden and Iraq used footage from a short-lived Swedish program called Halal TV.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video accurately compares weather reports from Sweden and Iraq.

title: Was an American Flag Displayed on the White House?
subtitle: A meme comparing White House light displays under the Trump and Obama administration used a digitally altered image.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A meme shows the American flag displayed on the White House in 2017, and a rainbow display in 2016.

title: Does a Viral Image Show People Lining Up to Surrender Their Pets for Euthanasia?
subtitle: An animal rescue organization provided a misleading - and inflammatory - description of a group of people waiting outside a Houston animal shelter.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A photograph shows people lining up outside a Houston, Texas shelter to turn in unwanted animals to be euthanized.

title: Is This Tennis Champion Julie Richardson - in 1898?
subtitle: An 1898 photograph of a woman named Julia Richardson was mistaken for a photograph of a 1980s tennis player with a similar name.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph from 1898 shows Julia Richardson, a tennis player who won six doubles championships.

title: Is This List of Democratic Shooters Accurate?
subtitle: A viral list charts dozens of shootings and assassination attempts purportedly committed by Democrats.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A meme accurately lists Democrats who have been involved in assassinations, assassination attempts, or mass shootings.

title: Millions of Muslims March Against the Islamic State?
subtitle: Reports that millions of Muslims protested against ISIS and that the news media ignored the event are misleading.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Millions of Muslims protested against the Islamic State in November 2016, but a "media blackout" prevented people from hearing about the event.

title: Are Indiana Muslims Appalled by an 'Accurate' List of Muhammad's Deeds?
subtitle: A billboard displaying hate speech is nowhere near accurate.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Indiana Muslims are appalled by a billboard displaying a list of deeds by the Prophet Muhammad even though it is accurate.

title: Is James Comey 'Best Friends' with Robert Mueller, And Is That Friendship a Conflict of Interest?
subtitle: Comey's attorney said that the two men know each other from working together but are hardly "best friends", and experts told us the relationship doesn't meet conflict of interest legal criteria.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Fired FBI Director James Comey and Special Counsel Bob Mueller are "best friends," which presents a conflict of interest in the Russia investigation.

title: Did President Trump Send Letters Lauding Middle Schoolers on Their 'Succuess'?
subtitle: A viral Facebook photograph purportedly showed a major spelling error in a congratulatory letter to students.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The Trump administration sent a letter to recipients of the President's Education Award, misspelling the word "success."

title: Did Queen Elizabeth Refuse to Retract an Invitation to President Donald Trump?
subtitle: A misleading article twists standard practice for the Queen into an attack on Sadiq Khan and gets important details wrong.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Queen Elizabeth contradicted London Mayor Sadiq Khan by "refusing to retract" an invitation to Donald Trump to visit the UK.

title: Did Londoners Chant in Support of Donald Trump in the Aftermath of a Terrorist Attack?
subtitle: A video shows a small group of far-right activists chanting the U.S. President's name, but it was filmed months before a June 2017 attack.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A video shows Londoners expressing support for the US President, following a June 2017 terrorist attack in the city

title: Is a Kentucky University Giving Black Students Free Tuition as an 'Apology' for Slavery?
subtitle: A non-binding vote by student leaders on a largely symbolic resolution has been misrepresented as official university policy.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Western Kentucky University will give black students free tuition as part of a program of reparations for slavery

title: Did a Valedictorian Drop Out Just Before Graduating to Become a CEO?
subtitle: Gio Managadze wrote a viral Facebook post claiming he was valedictorian at the University of Maryland, but dropped out just before graduating to pursue his dreams.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Gio Managadze dropped out of the University of Maryland just before graduating as valedictorian to become a CEO.

title: Did President Trump's Twitter Account Gain Five Million New Bot Followers in Three Days?
subtitle: According to archived images of Trump's Twitter page, rumors of a surge in followers were greatly exaggerated.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: President Donald Trump got five million new Twitter followers in three days, and most of them are bots.

title: Does Texas Ban Non-Christians from Adopting Children?
subtitle: House Bill 3859 would allow adoption agencies to use "religious beliefs" as a criterion for screening prospective parents.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: A law passed in Texas would ban non-Christians from adopting children.

title: Did Mitch McConnell Vow to Block the Appointment of a Russia Investigation Special Prosecutor?
subtitle: Reports grossly misrepresent the Senate Majority Leader's actual statements.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Mitch McConnell said he would block the appointment of a special counsel to investigate Russian election interference

title: Is There a Link Between Terrorist Attacks and the 22nd Day of the Month?
subtitle: Theories that terrorist attacks are more likely on the 22nd use faulty data and completely miss the point about "anniversary" attacks.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: There is a meaningful link between terrorist attacks and the 22nd day of the month

title: Pope Francis Smiled with President Obama, Frowned with President Trump?
subtitle: An image comparing Pope Francis's mood during President Obama and President Trump's visits doesn't tell the entire story.
author: Dan Evon
statement: An image accurately compares Pope Francis' mood during a visit with President Obama and another visit with President Trump.

title: Does Cooking with Aluminum Foil Put You at Risk for Alzheimer's?
subtitle: Sensationalist stories about how cooking with aluminum foil could spur the onset of Alzheimer's rely on a number of untested assumptions that sometimes strain credulity.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Studies have demonstrated that cooking with aluminum foil can result in the ingestion of aluminum, which is a risk factor for Alzheimer's disease.

title: Sarah Furay Let Off Drug Charges Due to DEA Father?
subtitle: Poor reporting and a sensationalized title led some to believe that "adorable drug kingpin" Sarah Furay was let off scot-free due to her father's connections with the Drug Enforcement Agency.
author: Dan Evon
statement: "Adorable Drug Kingpin" Sarah Furay avoided charges due to her father's connection to the DEA.

title: Did Trump Say Americans Had 'No Right' To Protest Him?
subtitle: A hyperpartisan web site misquoted a legal motion filed by Trump's lawyer.
author: Dan Evon
statement: President Trump said that Americans had no right to protest against him.

title: Is Harvard University Segregating Graduation Ceremonies?
subtitle: A ceremony organized by black students at Harvard was spun into a rumor that the university is segregating their commencement events.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Harvard University is segregating graduation ceremonies based on race in 2017.

title: Does a 'Muslim Migrant' from Syria with Four Wives, 23 Children Receive $390,000 a Year in Benefits?
subtitle: Reports that a Syrian refugee was receiving close to $400,000 annually were based on incomplete information.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A Syrian refugee receives close to $400,000 in benefits a year from the German government in order to take care of his wives and children.

title: Has the Congressional Budget Office Scored the American Health Care Act?
subtitle: The CBO scored previous versions of the health care bill, but has not yet scored the one the House of Representatives voted on in May 2017.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The American Health Care Act was scored twice by the CBO and it went through four committees before the House voted on it.

title: Do E-Cigarettes Really Contain Ten Times the Carcinogens of Tobacco Cigarettes?
subtitle: According to rumors, a Japanese study found that electronic cigarettes contain far more cancer-causing ingredients found in tobacco products.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: A Japanese study found electronic cigarettes (popularly called "e-cigs") contain ten times as many carcinogens as tobacco cigarettes.

title: Did a Car Run Over Trump Protesters on a Highway?
subtitle: A video showing a car driving through a demonstration is real, but it took place in Brazil and has nothing to do with the Trump administration.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video shows a car driving through a crowd of anti-Trump protesters on the highway.

title: Clouds Over Mount Fuji
subtitle: A spectacular video purportedly showing clouds rolling over Japan's Mount Fuji was digitally created from a still photograph.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video shows clouds rolling over Mount Fuji.

title: Can You Use Peanut Butter to Diagnose Alzheimer's Disease?
subtitle: This claim is based on an incomplete reading of an area of research that is still in its infancy.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Peanut butter can be used to diagnose Alzheimer's Disease.

title: Was a Protester Throwing Explosives Into a Berkeley Crowd Before She Was Punched?
subtitle: There's no evidence Louise Rosealma was using a glass bottle she appeared to be holding as an incendiary device.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Louise Rosealma was photographed holding an explosive device made from a glass bottle before she was punched by Nathan Damigo.

title: Did a U.S. Federal Court Rule That Women are Free to Display Their Breasts in Public?
subtitle: Reports that women in the U.S. can now go topless anywhere without fear of legal reprisal are not accurate.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Due to a recent court ruling, It is now legal for women in the U.S. to display their breasts in public.

title: Did a British Mom Lose Custody of Her Kids for 'Co-Sleeping'?
subtitle: Various news sites overemphasized one aspect of a case involving repeated injuries to two children.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: A British mother lost custody of her children because she ignored warnings about 'co-sleeping' with her children.

title: “Sour Honey' is a Cure for Cancer?
subtitle: While there is a limited amount of science behind some medical claims about bee propolis (marketed as "sour honey"), its promotion as a cure that is withheld from the public by Hillary Clinton and her pharmaceutical cronies is a marketing ploy.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: There is a proven natural cure for cancer called sour honey, but pharmaceutical companies and politicians are trying to keep it under wraps for financial gain.

title: Babies Born In-Flight Get Free Air Travel for Life?
subtitle: Although babies born in-flight are occasionally given free air travel for the rest of their lives by the carrier, it's a rare occurrence and not a standard practice.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Babies born in-flight are given free air travel by the airline for the rest of their lives.

title: Did Ben Carson Discover $500 Billion in Accounting Errors at HUD?
subtitle: An audit of Housing and Urban Development's books was carried out by the Office of the Inspector General and found an aggregate of billions in accounting errors.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: HUD director Ben Carson found more than $500 billion in accounting errors at the federal agency.

title: Crayola to Retire 'Dandelion' Colored Crayon Due to White House Pressure?
subtitle: The claim that the White House asked Crayola to drop the "dandelion" crayon because children were using it to create unflattering portraits of President Trump was satire.
author: David Emery
statement: Crayola announced they are removing the "dandelion" color from their basic box of 24 crayons due to a complaint from the White House that children were using it to create unflattering portraits of President Trump.

title: Did South Africa's President Purchase the World's Most Expensive Aircraft?
subtitle: A series of photographs purportedly showing a luxurious aircraft purchased by South African president Jacob Zuma are pictures of an unrelated airplane.
author: Dan Evon
statement: President Zuma of South Africa purchased the world's most expensive plane.

title: Is Twice-Boiled Water “Toxic”?
subtitle: Water is water, regardless of how many times it has boiled. The assertion that it becomes toxic rests on the scale-challenged mechanism of concentrating harmful components already present in the water.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Boiling the same water twice will make your water dangerous to drink.

title: Three Reasons You Should Stop Eating Peanut Butter Cups
subtitle: A viral post misrepresents the science behind three additives in the popular peanut butter and chocolate treat.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Three additives in peanut butter cups, soy lecithin, PGPR, and TBHQ, are inherently dangerous and should be avoided.

title: Crime in Sweden, Part II: Are Refugee Men Overrepresented in Swedish Crime?
subtitle: Claims that newly-arrived asylum seekers are causing a crime wave in Sweden are not supported by data or local officials.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Recently-arrived asylum seekers are perpetrating the majority of crime in Sweden.

title: Should People Call the Police if They See a New Guinea Flatworm?
subtitle: Claims that this invasive species presents a 911-level emergency overstate the risk that they pose to humans, and conflate ecological risks with medical ones.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: A recent invasion of New Guinea Flatworms in Florida poses a significant risk to human health and a sighting of this non-native animal should be reported to authorities by calling 911.

title: All 8 Supreme Court Justices Stand in Solidarity Against Trump SCOTUS Pick?
subtitle: Supreme Court justices did not pen a "letter" saying  President Trump was "completely wrong in choosing Neil Gorsuch" to fill a vacant seat on the court.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: All eight Supreme Court justices penned a "letter" saying  President Trump was "completely wrong in choosing Neil Gorsuch" to fill a vacant seat on the court.

title: Does the “Slime” Craze Bring Serious Health Risks?
subtitle: Science does not support the wild claims of potential health problems caused by this sticky DIY craze.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: “Slime,” a do-it-yourself gooey craft project containing borax, white glue, and shaving cream, comes with serious health risks.

title: Are Drug Dealers Selling Strawberry Meth to Kids?
subtitle: A warning to parents claimed drug dealers sell flavored, pink methamphetamine known as 'Strawberry Quick' to children.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Drug dealers are selling colored and flavored crystal methamphetamine known as "Strawberry Quick" to children.

title: Were Mysterious Caves Used by the Knights Templar Recently Discovered in Shropshire?
subtitle: Misleading headlines inaccurately suggested that long-documented caves in Shropshire, England were recently discovered (again).
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: An individual stumbled upon a network of mysterious caves in Shropshire, once used by the Knights Templar for secretive rituals.

title: Is This a Giant Insect Called a 'Georgian Speekle'?
subtitle: An image of a giant isopod is frequently shared along with the claim that it shows an insect first discovered in a garage in Georgia.
author: Dan Evon
statement: An image shows a "Georgian Speekle," one of the world's scariest insects.

title: Is the GOP's Obamacare Replacement Called 'World's Greatest Healthcare Plan of 2017'?
subtitle: An alternative bill authored by a Texas Republican has an auspicious title, but it's not the one backed by the Republican majority.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Is the GOP's Obamacare Replacement Called 'World's Greatest Healthcare Plan of 2017'?

title: Did 122 Prisoners Released from Guantanamo by President Obama Return to the Battlefield?
subtitle: Although 122 detainees transferred from Guantanamo Bay were found to have subsequently engaged in terrorist activities, 113 of those detainees were released under the administration of President George W. Bush.
author: Dan Evon
statement: 122 detainees released from confinement at Guantanamo Bay under President Obama have re-engaged in terrorist activities.

title: American Pediatricians Issue Statement That Transgenderism Is 'Child Abuse'?
subtitle: It was an official-sounding but fringe group of politically motivated pediatricians who issued a statement on gender, not the respected American Academy of Pediatrics.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The U.S.'s leading group of pediatricians issued a strong statement condemning tolerance of gender dysphoria in children.

title: Did John McCain Solicit a Campaign Contribution from the Russian Government?
subtitle: A letter sent to the Russian envoy in 2008 soliciting campaign contributions was an apparent error.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: John McCain solicited campaign contributions from Russia.

title: Did a Judge Rule That CNN Is 'Fake News'?
subtitle: The seemingly damning claim was based on a misstatement of a court ruling in a defamation suit.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: A federal judge ruling in a defamation suit declared that CNN was "fake news."

title: Did California Divert Dam Repair Funds to Programs for 'Illegals'?
subtitle: Money for the state's dam infrastructure does not come from the same fund as programs that would pay for programs serving immigrants, either with or without documents.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The state of California ignored structural issues with the Oroville dam and paid for programs to benefit undocumented people instead.

title: Does a Video Show Muslim Refugees Rioting in France?
subtitle: A video captures a Paris demonstration mounted over allegations of a police rape, an incident that had little to do with Muslim refugees.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video shows a Muslim refugees rioting and taking over an area in France.

title: Were Anti-Immigrant Demonstrations in Poland Ignored by News Media?
subtitle: Nationalists marched on Poland's independence day (11 November 2015), but the demonstrations weren't ignored by news media in Europe.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Massive anti-immigrant demonstrations in Poland were ignored by news media in Europe.

title: Is It Illegal to Be Fat in Japan?
subtitle: A law in Japan requires older citizens to undergo yearly weight exams but does not make it illegal for anyone to be overweight.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: A law in Japan makes it illegal for citizens of that country to be fat.

title: Government Eliminating Test Strip Subsidy for Diabetics?
subtitle: The Australian government has limited test strip subsidies for some diabetics, but there's been no change to how the U.S. government is handling them.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The government is eliminating a subsidy that helps diabetics acquire blood glucose test strips.

title: Did Coretta Scott King Thank Jeff Sessions in a Speech?
subtitle: Coretta Scott King acknowledged Senator Jeff Sessions (as well as many other politicians) in a dedicatory speech, but she didn't single him out for praise or specifically thank him.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video shows Coretta Scott King thanking Jeff Sessions during her remarks at the dedication of the Rosa Parks Library.

title: Did Stephen Colbert and Rachel Maddow Launch a 'Fire the Fool' Anti-Trump Rally?
subtitle: A 'Fire the Fool' rally against President Trump was announced in February 2017, but the event wasn't planned by Stephen Colbert or Rachel Maddow.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Stephen Colbert and Rachel Maddow are organizing a 'Fire The Fool' rally against President Trump.

title: Are Non-Citizens Being Registered to Vote Without Their Knowledge?
subtitle: A popular Facebook post asserted green card holders were being registered to vote without their knowing about it, creating grounds for their deportation.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Green Card holders are being illegally registered to vote without their knowledge or consent in order to create legal grounds for their deportation.

title: Did President Trump Ease Sanctions Against Russia's Intelligence Agency As a 'Gift' to Putin?
subtitle: The U.S. Treasury department updated President Obama's sanctions against the Russia's Federal Security Service to allow U.S. companies to continue selling consumer technology to Russian citizens.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: President Trump lifted sanctions against Russia as a "gift" to Putin.

title: Did President Trump Rename 'Black History Month' to 'African-American History Month'?
subtitle: Rumors claimed President Trump changed the name of 'Black History Month,' but he wasn't the first president to refer to February as "African-American History Month.'
author: Dan Evon
statement: President Trump changed the name of Black History Month to African-American History Month.

title: Did President Obama Ban Muslims from Entering the United States in 2011?
subtitle: Comparisons between a 2011 Obama administration slowdown on processing Iraqi visas and President Trump's stay on immigration from seven countries are inaccurate.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: President Obama banned immigration from Iraq for six months in 2011, but the media buried the story.

title: Did President Trump Alter the United States Constitution?
subtitle: Despite rumors, the White House has not rewritten the actual Constitution to change the word "persons" to "citizens."
author: Dan Evon
statement: President Donald Trump changed the constitution to read "citizens" instead of "persons."

title: Did Pope Francis Condemn President Trump for Issuing a Travel Ban?
subtitle: Pope Francis said it was hypocritical to "call yourself a Christian and chase away a refugee," but the pontiff made that comment before Donald Trump was elected president.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Pope Francis condemned Donald Trump for issuing a temporary travel ban in January 2017.

title: Senate Voted 51-48 to Repeal the Affordable Care Act?
subtitle: Rumors about a repeal of the ACA, also known as Obamacare, were alarming to many but mostly inaccurate.
author: Dan Evon
statement: The senate voted 51-48 to repeal the Affordable Care Act on 12 January 2017.

title: Is Chili's Donating 15 Percent of Every Sale to Planned Parenthood?
subtitle: A screenshot with partial information created the inaccurate impression the Chili's restaurant chain is donating 15 percent of all their sales to Planned Parenthood.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The Chili's restaurant chain donates 15 percent of every sale to Planned Parenthood.

title: Did Trump Hang a Photograph of the Women's March at the White House?
subtitle: A photograph of Donald Trump's inauguration featuring the wrong date was hung at the White House, but the image did not show the Women's March on Washington
author: Dan Evon
statement: Donald Trump hung a photograph of the Women's March at the White House believing that it showed his inauguration.

title: Does Planned Parenthood Provide No Prenatal Care, Only Abortions?
subtitle: A video investigation purportedly showed that Planned Parenthood does not offer health services for women such as prenatal care, only abortions.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video investigation showed that Planned Parenthood lies about providing prenatal care.

title: Did President Trump Shut Down the White House Phone-In Comment Line?
subtitle: The White House phone-in comment line was non-operational in January 2017, but the change took place during President Obama's administration.
author: Dan Evon
statement: President Trump's administration shut down the White House phone comment line.

title: Is the U.S. Pulling Out of the United Nations?
subtitle: A new congressional bill seeks to end U.S. participation in the United Nations, but the same bill has been introduced to each new Congress for 20 years running.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: One of the first acts of the Trump administration was to seek the end of U.S. participation in the United Nations.

title: Is This Really Donald Trump's Inauguration Poem?
subtitle: A poem inspired by Donald Trump's inauguration was widely shared as if it were the official poem for the event. It is not.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Donald Trump's official inauguration poem describes Barack Obama as a tyrant.

title: Has the ACLU Demanded that Police Remove Body Cams During Inauguration Protests?
subtitle: A misconstrued comment from an ACLU representative led to rumors the organization demanded police turn off body cameras during January 2017 protests in Washington, D.C.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The American Civil Liberties Union has demanded police in Washington, D.C. disable their body cameras for the duration of inaugural protests in 2017.

title: Did Snoop Dogg 'Threaten' Any Black Artist Who Performs at Trump's Inauguration?
subtitle: The famous rapper declared he would "roast" (i.e., make fun of) black artists who performed at Donald Trump's inauguration, bruising nothing more than their egos.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Rapper Snoop Dogg threatened any black artist who performs at Donald Trump's inauguration.

title: Can TV Viewers Protest Donald Trump's Inauguration by Changing the Channel?
subtitle: A Facebook message urges viewers not to watch Donald Trump's inauguration, but that form of protest likely won't affect the event's ratings.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Television viewers can drastically lower the TV ratings for Donald Trump's inauguration by changing the channel.

title: Was the Raggedy Ann Doll Modeled After a Child Killed by a Vaccine?
subtitle: Raggedy Ann's creator filed patents for the doll several months before his daughter fell ill and died, rendering an old claim about vaccines chronologically impossible.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Raggedy Ann dolls were created by a grief-stricken father who lost his daughter to a vaccine-related illness, and who wished to broadcast the risks of vaccination.

title: Did Denzel Washington Criticize Meryl Streep?
subtitle: Actor Denzel Washington said that making movies was a luxury, a comment that was unrelated to Meryl Streep's controversial 2017 Golden Globes speech.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Denzel Washington criticized Meryl Streep for making a political speech during the 2017 Golden Globes award ceremony.

title: Did President Obama Award Himself a Distinguished Public Service Medal?
subtitle: President Obama received a medal bestowed by the Secretary of Defense, not himself, that has been awarded to previous Presidents.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: President Obama awarded himself the Department of Defense Medal for Distinguished Public Service.

title: Was a Vermont Power Grid Infiltrated by Russian Hackers?
subtitle: The Washington Post was heavily criticized for jumping the gun and suggesting a Vermont power company had been targeted for disruption by Russian hackers.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A computer infected by malware proved a Vermont power company has been targeted for disruption by Russian hackers.

title: Republican Congress Approved 'Trump TV'?
subtitle: A misleading article reported that Republicans had approved the creation of a taxpayer-funded network called "Trump TV."
author: Dan Evon
statement: Congress has approved the creation of a taxpayer-funded network called "Trump TV."

title: Did Obama Sign a Bill Making Alternative Media Illegal?
subtitle: Numerous small web outlets inaccurately asserted that President Obama signed a "Christmas bill" criminalizing alternative media in December 2016.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: In December 2016, President Obama signed a bill criminalizing alternative media.

title: Telling Siri to 'Charge My Phone to 100%' Summons Police
subtitle: Siri can do a lot of things, but she won't summon police surreptitiously in response to the command "charge my phone to 100 percent."
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Telling Siri to "charge my phone to 100 percent" will cause the virtual assistant to surreptitiously dial 911 or summon emergency services.

title: 'Freedom Concert' Being Planned, But No Details Announced
subtitle: Some concert promoters are toying with the idea of a "Freedom Concert," but no official plans have yet been announced.
author: Dan Evon
statement: An image shows a real flyer for a "Freedom Concert" scheduled for Inauguration Day.

title: Did Every Single School Marching Band in DC Just Boycott Trump's Inauguration?
subtitle: While many high school marching bands did not apply to play at Donald Trump's inauguration, these schools cited a variety of reasons and are not boycotting the event.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Every high school marching band in Washington D.C. is boycotting Donald Trump's inauguration.

title: Do Women Need More Sleep Than Men Because Their Brains Work Harder?
subtitle: This zombie of a viral news story does not accurately reflect either science or the views of the scientist the authors allegedly quote.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Women need more sleep than men because their brains get more use on a day-to-day basis.

title: Do Tony and John Podesta Match Madeleine McCann Police Sketches?
subtitle: In a classic conspiracy theory trope, rumormongers "spotted" the Podesta brothers in police sketches linked to the Madeleine McCann disappearance.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Police sketches of Madeleine McCann's alleged kidnappers are a perfect match for Tony and John Podesta.

title: National Park Service Denying Inauguration Protest Permits?
subtitle: The National Park Service has not denied all demonstration permits through March 2017 in an effort to block the Million Women March (or other protests).
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The National Park Service specifically blocked the Million Women March as well as all other demonstrations through March 2017.

title: Donald Trump to Remain on 'The Apprentice' after Inauguration
subtitle: Donald Trump is retaining an "Apprentice" producing credit, but will not be involved with the program in any capacity.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Donald Trump will be a "part-time President" and keep his job on "Celebrity Apprentice."

title: Paul Ryan Said Free Lunches Give Children 'Empty Souls'?
subtitle: In December 2016, a purported quote that the House Speaker made in 2014 about public assistance went viral.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: In 2016, Speaker Paul Ryan said free lunches gave children a "full stomach" but left them with an "empty soul."

title: Target Blocks Israel from E-Commerce Access?
subtitle: Despite rumors to the contrary, Target and Target.com have not been blocked in Israel.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Target.com or Target blocked Israel from accessing and shopping their web site.

title: Harry & David Says Company is 'Neutral' on Racism, Neo-Nazis?
subtitle: Social media users claimed that representatives told them it the company has no opinion about racism, but the company says otherwise.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The company Harry & David had no concerns about advertising with Breitbart, saying they were "neutral" on issues of racism and anti-Semitism.

title: University Forced Students to Wear Hijabs for Event?
subtitle: While the Muslim Student Association at the University of Wisconsin-Madison held a "'Hijabi for a Day" event during Islam Appreciation Week, the school did not "force" students to wear hijabs.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Administrators at the University of Wisconsin forced students to wear hijabs during Islam Appreciation Week.

title: Did the White House Press Secretary Say That WWII Vets Upset About Japan Visit Should 'Get Over It'?
subtitle: Comments made by Josh Earnest about diplomatic relations with Japan around the 2016 anniversary of Pearl Harbor did not include a directive that veterans should "get over it."
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest said World War II veterans who felt "embittered" by diplomatic relations with Japan on the anniversary of Pearl Harbor in 2016 should "get over it."

title: Clinton Portrait Hung with Christmas Decorations at White House
subtitle: While Hillary Clinton's portrait was surrounded by Christmas decorations in 2016, this painting has been at the White House (and decorated each year) since 2004.
author: Dan Evon
statement: President Obama hung a portrait of Hillary Clinton at the White House as part of his 2016 Christmas decorations.

title: United Airlines to Begin Charging for Use of Overhead Storage?
subtitle: A number of articles inaccurately reported that United Airlines would begin charging passengers for the use of overhead bins on flights.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: United Airlines will begin charging for overhead bin space.

title: Your Christmas Tree Is (Probably) Not Full of Lyme Disease Bearing Ticks
subtitle: Viral warnings about disease-carrying ticks in Christmas trees ignore much of the scientific literature on how ticks and Lyme disease actually operate.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: If you use a real Christmas tree, you run the risk of bringing Lyme disease-transmitting ticks into your home.

title: Did Tom and Jerry 'Commit Suicide'?
subtitle: The cartoon cat and mouse duo survived explosions, burns, falling anvils, misplaced rakes, and even gunshot wounds.
author: Dan Evon
statement: The final episode of Tom And Jerry ended with both characters committing suicide.

title: Levi Strauss Banned Guns From Stores?
subtitle: Levi Strauss CEO Chip Bergh did pen an open letter requesting that gun owners refrain from bringing their weapons into stores, but Levi Strauss has not instituted a policy change or a gun ban.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Levi Strauss clothing stores have banned all guns.

title: Did Thomas Edison's Mother Lie About a Letter Expelling Him from School?
subtitle: A heartwarming anecdote tells of the future inventor's mother fibbing to her son about his expulsion from school due to “mental deficiencies."
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Thomas Edison's mother lied about the contents of a letter from her son's school informing her that the school had expelled him for “mental deficiencies.”

title: Breitbart News App Removed From the Apple Store?
subtitle: Rumors circulated that Apple was purging its app store of "fake news" web sites - starting with Breitbart's news app.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Apple's purge of "fake news" apps from the App store started with the removal of Breitbart News in November 2016.

title: Was a Minnesota Man Jailed for Having a Windmill on His Property?
subtitle: A story about a man purportedly arrested over his efforts to use wind power on his own property is inaccurate and misleading.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: A Minnesota man was jailed simply for possessing a windmill on his property.

title: Can Ghost Peppers Burn a Hole in Your Esophagus?
subtitle: Stories about a man whose throat was burned through by an extremely hot pepper were frightening, but not entirely accurate.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A very spicy pepper burned a hole through a man's esophagus.

title: Law Charges Protesters With Terrorism?
subtitle: A Republican senator proposed a bill that would classify some forms of protesting as "economic terrorism," but web sites reporting on a "new law" in late 2016 were spreading misinformation.
author: Dan Evon
statement: People protesting Donald Trump's presidency will be charged with terrorism under a new law.

title: Obama Sets Record With 572 Pages of New Regulations in One Day?
subtitle: The number of pages added to the Federal Register is not indicative of new regulations being added.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: President Obama added a record 572 pages of new regulations in one day.

title: Celebrity Cruise Lines Attacks Trump and His Supporters in New Ad?
subtitle: Celebrity Cruise Lines released an advertisement addressing some of Donald Trump's talking points from the 2016 presidential election, but they did not say that his supporters were not welcome.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Celebrity Cruise lines released an ad saying that Donald Trump's supporters were no longer welcome on their ships.

title: WikiLeaks Asks President-Elect Trump to Pardon Julian Assange as Compensation?
subtitle: WikiLeaks has long sought relief from U.S. investigations and interference, and Julian Assange hasn't asked President-Elect Trump for a compensatory pardon.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Julian Assange asked President-Elect Donald Trump for a pardon in exchange for his help in defeating Hillary Clinton.

title: Pepsi CEO Tells Trump Supporters to Take Their Business Elsewhere
subtitle: Pepsi CEO Indra Nooyi never told supporters of Donald Trump to "take their business elsewhere," implicitly or explicitly.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Pepsi CEO Indra Nooyi told Donald Trump supporters to "take their business elsewhere."

title: Trump Win Prompts Ford to Move Manufacturing from Mexico to Ohio
subtitle: Ford did not move manufacturing to Ohio from Mexico because Donald Trump was elected president in November 2016.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: After Donald Trump won the 2016 election, Ford decided to move production of their vehicles from Mexico to Ohio.

title: Police Horse Kicks Black Lives Matter Protester
subtitle: A police horse kicked a student in Ontario, Canada, after she sneaked up and slapped it, but the incident had nothing to do with Black Lives Matter.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A police horse kicked a Black Lives Matter protester.

title: Trump's First Order: Anyone Burning an American Flag to Be Charged with Treason
subtitle: A disreputable web site published an article falsely claiming that Donald Trump's "first order" as President would be to make burning an American flag a treasonous act.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Donald Trump announced that his "first order" as President would be to make flag burning a treasonous act.

title: Yale Cancels Midterms After Students Were Upset by Trump's Win
subtitle: Rumors claimed classes and exams were canceled at Yale due to student distress over Donald Trump's win, but the underlying facts didn't appear so polarized.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Midterm exams at Yale were canceled because students were too upset by Donald Trump's election.

title: NBC Accidentally Posts Election Results a Week Early
subtitle: In what is becoming a common pre-election conspiracy-driving glitch, an NBC affiliate's software test was interpreted as evidence election results were rigged.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Chattanooga-area NBC affiliate WRCB inadvertently exposed the rigging of 2016 election results in Hillary Clinton's favor.

title: Obama, Warren Unfollow Hillary Clinton
subtitle: Several web sites falsely claimed President Obama, Elizabeth Warren, and other Democratic politicians unfollowed Hillary Clinton on social media before the 2016 presidential election.
author: Dan Evon
statement: President Obama, Elizabeth Warren and other top Democratic officials have distanced themselves from Hillary Clinton by unfollowing her on social media.

title: Drinking Tequila Provides Many Health Benefits?
subtitle: Unfortunately, myriad claims about tequila's putative health benefits are not rooted in science or research.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Tequila fights viruses, aids weight loss, and is beneficial for people afflicted with gastrointestinal illness.

title: Russia Paid Donald Trump Millions of Dollars
subtitle: ABC reported in September 2016 that Trump has business interests in Russia, not that the Russian government paid him money.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: ABC News has reported that Donald Trump received millions of dollars from Russia.

title: Loretta Lynch Pleads Fifth Over Iran Payment
subtitle: Attorney General Loretta Lynch did not invoke her Fifth Amendment protections to avoid giving incriminating testimony about the Iran money transfer.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Attorney General Loretta Lynch invoked her Fifth Amendment protection not to incriminate herself over the Obama administration's transfer of money to Iran.

title: Ecstasy in Halloween Candy?
subtitle: Despite Facebook warnings, there's little reason to expect drug-laced Gummi bears and Ecstasy tablets will be found in kids' trick-or-treat bags this Halloween.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Parents should keep any eye out for drug-laced Gummy bears and ecstasy (MDMA) disguised as Halloween candy being distributed to trick-or-treaters.

title: Obama Golf Outing with Tiger Woods Cost Nearly $4 Million?
subtitle: President Obama didn't spend $3.6  million in taxpayer funds just to play golf with Tiger Woods.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Taxypayers paid $4 million for President Obama to play golf with Tiger Woods.

title: Did Doctors Warn Never Clean Your Child with Baby Wipes?
subtitle: A viral blog post warning about the dangers of baby wipes contained several inaccurate - and potentially dangerous - pieces of misinformation.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Doctors are now warning parents to never use baby wipes because they contain a "chemical" called methylisothiazolinone.

title: Department of Justice Says Efforts to Stop Voter Fraud Are Illegal?
subtitle: The DOJ issued a statement saying that voter intimidation is against federal law, not that accusations of voter fraud are illegal.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The Department of Justice says that attempting to document or report voter fraud is against federal law.

title: Scientists Say Strange Signals Are 'Probably' Coming from Extraterrestrial Intelligence?
subtitle: Astronomers analyzed a database of spectra from 2.5 million stars and were unable to explain the nature of 234 of them, but while the authors of the study did indeed propose extraterrestrials as an explanation, their certainty has been exaggerated in the media and tempered by other scientists.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Two scientists who analyzed 2.5 million stars have concluded that the signals coming from a small fraction of them are “probably” caused by aliens.

title: Minecraft 'Sex Mods'
subtitle: Parental pearl-clutching about Minecraft "sex mods" is largely based on misinformation about the popular game.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Minecraft has a newly-discovered "sex mod" of which parents should be aware and exercise caution (or restrict the game from their children entirely).

title: Texas Vote Switching
subtitle: Although rumors of "vote switching" in Texas are rampant, we found only one case in which a report was investigated, and it was found to be unsubstantiated.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Voters across Texas have witnessed their votes switch from "straight Republican" to Democrat on compromised voting machines.

title: 6,000 Muslims with Forged Papers Caught at Southern Border
subtitle: A claim that 6,000 Muslim migrants were captured at the U.S.-Mexico border with forged papers is unsubstantiated.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: 6,000 Muslim migrants with forged papers were captured trying to cross the U.S.-Mexico border.

title: Did 30,000 Scientists Declare Climate Change a Hoax?
subtitle: More than 30,000 people may have signed a petition challenging the veracity of anthropogenic global warming, but one doesn't have to be a climate scientist, or even a practicing scientist, to sign that document.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: 30,000 scientists have signed a petition arguing that there is no convincing scientific evidence for anthropogenic climate change.

title: WikiLeaks E-Mail Says Obama Directed His Supporters to Engage in 'All-American Voter Fraud'
subtitle: One WikiLeaks e-mail referenced unproven rumors that the Obama campaign had "flooded" the 2008 Iowa Democratic caucuses with out-of-state voters.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The WikiLeaks 'Podesta archive' included an e-mail that stated President Obama had "directed his supporters in Colorado to engage in a little all-American voter fraud."

title: Kenneth Copeland: 'Whoever Doesn't Vote for Trump Will Be Guilty for the Civil War We Planned'
subtitle: A fake news site overstated televangelist Kenneth Copeland's anti-Hillary Clinton rant -- but not by much.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Televangelist Kenneth Copeland says "civil war" will unfold if Donald Trump loses the presidential election.

title: Bernie Sanders Suggests Election Is Rigged, Unendorses Hillary Clinton
subtitle: A post on Bernie Sanders' Facebook page did not suggest he believes the presidential election is "rigged" or indicate he was "unendorsing" Hillary Clinton.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Sen. Bernie Sanders said the election was "rigged" and "unendorsed" Hillary Clinton

title: Whole Foods Market Bans Gendered Language
subtitle: A "WholeFoods" business in Australia asked customers to be mindful of gendered language, but the business isn't connected with the American Whole Foods Market organic grocery chain.
author: Dan Evon
statement: The Whole Foods Market organic grocery chain has banned the use of gendered language.

title: Hillary Refers to Muslims as 'Sand N*****s' in WikiLeaks Dump?
subtitle: The term "sand n*****" does appear in e-mail sent by Hillary Clinton and published by Wikileaks, but the Democratic presidential nominee did not use the term herself to describe Muslims.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Hillary Clinton called Muslims "sand n*ggers" in an email leaked by Wikileaks.

title: President Obama Demands 'Ribs and Pussy Too?'
subtitle: A clip of Barack Obama reading from his book "Dreams of My Father" has been shared out of context.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video surfaced in October 2016 showing President Obama demanding "ribs and pussy."

title: Mike Pence Signed Law Forcing Women to Pay for Fetus 'Funerals'?
subtitle: The measure, which concerned the disposal of fetal remains, was part of a bigger anti-abortion law passed by state legislators in March 2016.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Republican vice presidential candidate Mike Pence signed legislation forcing women to hold funerals for miscarried or aborted fetuses.

title: Muslims Demand Army Change Its Dress Code to Include Turbans and Beards
subtitle: The Department of Defense announced back in January 2014 that religious dress accommodations had been added to uniform guidelines on a case-by-case basis.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Muslims demanded the U.S. Army change its dress code to allow beards and turbans.

title: Hillary Clinton Lost $6 Billion at the State Department?
subtitle: An inspector general's report stated that $6 billion in U.S. State Dept. expenditures weren't properly accounted for during Hillary Clinton's tenure there, but the money never went "missing."
author: David Emery
statement: $6 billion went missing from the U.S. State Department while Hillary Clinton was in charge.

title: Donald Trump Didn't Say Vets with PTSD Are 'Weak'
subtitle: GOP presidential candidate Donald Trump did not say veterans suffering from PTSD are "weak," "unfit," and "can't handle" military service.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Donald Trump said veterans suffering from PTSD are "weak," "unfit," and "can't handle" military service.

title: Veterans' Corpses Found Rotting in Chicago VA's Morgue?
subtitle: A clickbait web site used a misleading picture to advance a rumor about unclaimed veterans' corpses in a VA hospital.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Dozens of veterans' bodies were left to rot in a Chicago-area VA hospital's morgue.

title: Hillary Clinton Fundraiser Recording
subtitle: Leaked audio captured Hillary Clinton talking about disappointed millennial voters, but she didn't call them "basement dwellers."
author: Dan Evon
statement: Hillary Clinton called millennial supporters of Bernie Sanders "basement dwellers."

title: Hillary Clinton Targets Family Farms with 65% Estate Tax?
subtitle: Hillary Clinton has been criticized for proposing a 65% estate tax that would put family farms out of business. Is that an accurate representation of her plan?
author: David Emery
statement: Hillary Clinton has proposed a 65% estate tax rate which would force farm families to give up their businesses.

title: Cancer-Causing Children's Snacks Made from Petroleum-Based Products
subtitle: A viral post suggests that your kid's snacks are laced with cancer-causing petroleum products, but scientific evidence to support these claims is lacking.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Snacks marketed to children are heavily laden with ingredients that cause cancer.

title: NAACP Said 'Black Cops Aren't Real Black People'
subtitle: Exaggerated reporting led to the false claim that the NAACP proclaimed "black cops are not real black people."
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The NAACP asserted black cops are "not real black people."

title: Two White Men Doused with Gasoline, Set on Fire by BLM
subtitle: A video showing two men on fire was shared with the false claims that it involved the Black Lives Matter movement and that the mainstream media were ignoring the story.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Two white men were doused in gasoline and set on fire by Black Lives Matter members, and the story was "censored" by the media.

title: Has Child Prostitution Been Legalized in California?
subtitle: A rumor that California had legalized prostitution for minors was based on a faulty understanding of a new law.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: California has passed a law that legalizes child prostitution.

title: Dandelion Root Kills 98% of Cancer Cells in 48 Hours?
subtitle: Dandelion root is being studied for possible anti-cancer properties, but there's absolutely no proof it kills "98 percent of cancer cells in 48 hours."
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Dandelion root can kill 98 percent of cancer cells in 48 hours.

title: Lester Holt Wore an Earpiece During the Debate.  So What?
subtitle: Moderator Lester Holt did wear an earpiece during the first presidential debate of 2016, but he didn't break any debate rules in doing so.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Lester Holt broke the rules during the first presidential debate of 2016 by wearing an earpiece.

title: UN Demands U.S. Pay Reparations for Slavery
subtitle: The United Nations has not ordered the United States to pay reparations to black citizens for slavery.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The United Nations (UN) ruled that the United States must pay slavery reparations to black Americans.

title: Was Miss Universe Alicia Machado a 'Porn Star'?
subtitle: Former Miss Universe Alicia Machado was characterized as a 'porn star' shortly after she was mentioned by Hillary Clinton during a presidential debate in September 2016.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Former Miss Universe Alicia Machado was a 'porn star.'

title: Michael Savage Removed from the Airwaves for Discussing Clinton's Health
subtitle: Cryptic tweets sent by radio host Michael Savage led to rumors he was fired or replaced with a "liberal host" after discussing the topic of Hillary Clinton's health.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Radio personality Michael Savage was fired because he talked about Hillary Clinton's health on the air.

title: Did Tiffany Chokers Originate as Slave Collars?
subtitle: Tiffany & Co. never made or sold slave collars, and a viral image of a slave collar is not from an exhibit at the National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington, D.C.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: An image depicts a Tiffany-made slave collar on display at the National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington, D.C.

title: New York Police Officer Caught on Camera Raping Girl?
subtitle: The sharing of a questionable video wrongly identifies a South African officer charged with rape as an NYPD employee.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A New York City police officer was caught on camera raping a teenage girl.

title: Are Police Allowed to 'Pop Hoods' to Block Dash Cams?
subtitle: Two images of three Danville, Virginia, police vehicles with their hoods raised led to incorrect claims the practice was sanctioned to obstruct dash cams.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Image depicts police in Danville, Virginia, purposely obstructing dash cams by lifting the hoods of their vehicles.

title: Did Scientists Cure Cancer, But No One Took Notice?
subtitle: Pharmaceutical companies aren't interested in a 'simple cure for cancer' because it hasn't been proved an effective treatment, not because it isn't patentable.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Researchers have found a simple cure for cancer, but major pharmaceutical companies are not interested because it isn't patentable.

title: President Obama Is Giving Mexico $75 Million to Build a Southern Border Wall
subtitle: The U.S. State Department is providing Mexico with assistance to help secure southern borders, but they didn't give Mexico $75 million to build a physical wall.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: President Obama is giving Mexico $75 million to build a wall on their southern border.

title: WikiLeaks Bombshell: Bill O'Reilly and Megan Kelly are Clinton Operatives
subtitle: Leaked e-mails from the Democratic National Committee don't suggest Bill O'Reilly and Megyn Kelly are surreptitious Clinton operatives.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: WikiLeaks revealed that Bill O'Reilly and Megyn Kelly are covert Hillary Clinton campaign operatives.

title: Syrian Refugees Complain About Slow Internet, No Television
subtitle: A video of Syrian refugees purportedly complaining about a lack of TVs and slow Internet service has been taken far out of context.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Syrian refugees in Europe are complaining about a lack of TVs, food quality, and "slow internet."

title: $42.4 Billion Consumer Rebate Program
subtitle: Misleading ads touting a "new law" that provides consumers with a "cash rebate on every single purchase" actually reference an old tax break that benefits only a small minority of taxpayers.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A new government program gives all taxpaying Americans the right to collect 'cash rebates' on nearly every single purchase.

title: Judges Rules the Government Can Ban Vegetable Gardens
subtitle: A landscaping dispute between homeowners and village codes in Miami Shores led to widespread rumors that a judge had ruled the government can ban vegetable gardens.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: A Florida judge ruled that the government can ban vegetable gardens because they're "ugly."

title: Gary Johnson Said Removal of Firing Pins Makes All Guns Fully Automatic?
subtitle: A quote about automatic weapons attributed to Libertarian presidential candidate Gary Johnson is actually a misconstrual of something his running mate said.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Libertarian presidential candidate Gary Johnson said "guns can be made full auto by removing the firing pins."

title: Is Sweden Moving to a 6-Hour Workday?
subtitle: Although some businesses in Sweden have started experimenting with a shorter workday, the country has not passed any laws mandating fewer work hours.
author: Dan Evon
statement: The country of Sweden is officially moving to a 6-hour workday.

title: Did Obama Call Americans 'Lazy' in an Overseas Speech?
subtitle: Pundits accused President Obama of insulting Americans after he used the word "lazy" during a town hall question-and-answer session in Laos.
author: David Emery
statement: Obama twice described Americans as "lazy" during a town hall meeting in Laos.

title: Five Nuclear Carriers in Harbor
subtitle: President Obama did not order five first-line U.S. aircraft carriers into port together in a shocking breach of military protocol.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: President Obama ordered five first-line U.S. aircraft carriers into port together in a shocking breach of military protocol.

title: FDA: Frosted Flakes are Healthier than Avocados
subtitle: A newspaper's video critique of FDA guidelines for healthy food led to claims the agency said Frosted Flakes are healthier than avocados.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The FDA said Frosted Flakes are healthier than avocados.

title: S.C. High School Bans American Flag from Football Games
subtitle: While a South Carolina high school principal prevented students from bringing a U.S. flag to a football game, the school did not issue a ban on the Stars and Stripes.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A South Carolina high school principal banned U.S. flags from football games.

title: Cheez-It Crackers and TBHQ
subtitle: Cheez-It brand crackers contain the synthetic preservative TBHQ, but the latter is not "created from butane," nor is it "toxic."
author: Dan Evon
statement: Cheez-It brand crackers contain the preservative TBHQ, which is made from butane and is dangerous to consume.

title: Mylan CEO Donated Money to the Clinton Foundation?
subtitle: The pharmaceutical company Mylan (manufacturer of the EpiPen), not their CEO personally, donated money to the Clinton Foundation.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Mylan CEO Heather Bresch donated a large sum of money to the Clinton Foundation.

title: Binghamton University Offers 'Stop White People' Course
subtitle: Some Binghamton University resident assistants utilized material with the words "stop white people" for an optional conference developed by students, but the school itself is not offering a course on that topic.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: SUNY Binghamton is offering a "Stop White People" course.

title: State Cuts Off Water to  Dakota Access Pipeline Protesters?
subtitle: Social media rumors inaccurately reported water was cut off to Native Americans protesting against the Dakota Access Pipeline.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The state cut off water access to Native Americans protesting the Dakota Access Pipeline.

title: New Dodge Challenger Features Elephant Skin Interior
subtitle: A Dodge Challenger SRT Hellcat was outfitted by a custom aftermarket shop with an elephant leather interior, but this option is not one provided by the car's manufacturer.
author: Dan Evon
statement: PIctures show that Dodge is offering an elephant skin interior with their new Challenger SRT Hellcat.

title: Is the Pacu a Testicle-Biting Fish?
subtitle: How the red-bellied pacu fish, a mostly vegetarian cousin of the piranha with human-like teeth, gained a reputation for biting off men's testicles.
author: David Emery
statement: The red-bellied pacu, an invasive species related to the piranha but with human-like teeth, is known to have bitten off men's testicles, killing at least two victims.

title: Hillary Clinton Refused to Congratulate American Gold Medalist?
subtitle: A misleading article reported that presidential candidate Hillary Clinton had "refused" to congratulate American gold medalist Ginny Thrasher.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Hillary Clinton refused to congratulate American gold medalist Ginny Thrasher.

title: Trump Said He'd Drop Out If Polls Showed Him Losing to Hillary?
subtitle: A nine-month-old 'Meet the Press' statement by Donald Trump about primary campaign polling was misleadingly applied to the presidential race in August 2016.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Donald Trump said on

title: President Obama Is Banning the 'Don't Tread on Me' Flag?
subtitle: Legal analyst Eugene Volokh's article about an EEOC decision pertaining to the Gadsden flag ("Don't Tread On Me") led to rumors the pennant has been banned.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: President Obama is banning the Gadsden Flag ("Don't Tread on Me") because it has been deemed racist.

title: Did Bernie Sanders Leave the Democratic Party?
subtitle: The Vermont senator will return to his roots as an Independent, but not as a protest over leaked information.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Sen. Bernie Sanders left the Democratic Party during the DNC (possibly as part of the #Demexit protest).

title: Elijah Cummings Said Democrats Gave Black People the Right to Vote?
subtitle: A meme claiming Rep. Elijah Cummings misattributed responsibility for the 15th Amendment during his 2016 DNC speech was mostly inaccurate itself.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Rep. Elijah Cummings incorrectly stated during his 2016 DNC speech that Democrats gave black people the right to vote.

title: Did Hillary Clinton Steal $200,000 in White House Furnishings?
subtitle: An Internet meme claiming that Hillary Clinton was forced to return $200,000 worth of furniture, china and art she "stole" from the White House is based on a grain of truth.
author: David Emery
statement: The Clintons were forced to return an estimated $200,000 in furniture, china and art they "stole" from the White House.

title: Pokemon Go Program Clears Shelter of Dogs Awaiting Adoption
subtitle: The details of a shelter's Pokemon Go dogwalking program were exaggerated for a heartstring-tugging viral Facebook post.
author: Kim LaCapria
